contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox political party |name = White Patriot Party |logo = |colorcode = #000000 |chairperson = |leader1_title = |leader1_name = |leader2_name = |leader3_title = |leader3_name = |founded = 1980 |dissolved = 1987 |headquarters = |student_wing = |youth_wing = |ideology = [[White supremacy]]<br>[[Anti-Semitism]]<br>[[Fascism]] |international = |colors = ''None'' |blank1_title = [[Political spectrum|Political position]] |blank1 = [[Far-right]] |website = ''N/A'' |country = United States }} The '''White Patriot Party''' ('''WPP''') was an [[United States|American]] [[anti-Semitism|anti-Semitic]] [[white supremacy|white supremacist]] [[paramilitary]] [[political party]] associated with [[Christian Identity]] and the [[Ku Klux Klan]]. It was led by its founder, [[Frazier Glenn Miller Jr.]], through various organizational incarnations. The organization began in the mid-1970s as the '''Carolina Knights of the Ku Klux Klan'''. It was involved in the [[Greensboro massacre|incident]] in [[Greensboro, North Carolina]] when a confrontation between Klansmen, Nazis and communists left five people dead. The organization became the '''Confederate Knights of the Ku Klux Klan''' in the early 1980s and the White Patriot Party in 1985.<ref>Michael and Judy Ann Newton eds. ''The Ku Klux Klan; an encyclopedia'' Garland Reference Library of the Social Science Vol.499 London and New York; Garland Publishing inc. 1991 pp.98, 395, 610</ref> At a time of a poor farming economy in [[North Carolina]], the group built support by blaming economic problems on [[Jew]]ish bankers. Estimates were that its numbers might have been as high as 3000. On April 6, 1987, the group [[Declaration of war|declared war]] against the federal government, which they called "[[Zionist Occupation Government]]" (ZOG).<ref>[http://web.archive.org/web/20070930013115/http://www.tkb.org/Group.jsp?groupID=127 "White Patriot Party (WPP)"], ''Terrorism Knowledge Base'', Memorial Institute for the Prevention of Terrorism, retrieved on April 8th, 2010</ref> The WPP collapsed after Miller violated an injunction against [[paramilitary]] activity and was convicted of threatening the [[civil rights]] activist [[Morris Dees]]. He was imprisoned from 1987-1990. In a 1988 [[sedition]] trial in Arkansas, Miller testified for the prosecution that he had received $200,000 in stolen money from [[The Order (group)|The Order]] to finance operations of the White Patriot Party.<ref name="Jackson">[http://www.splcenter.org/intel/intelreport/article.jsp?pid=840 Camille Jackson, "They're Back: A fresh batch of extremist ex-cons hits the streets"], ''[[Southern Poverty Law Center#Intelligence_Report|Intelligence Report]]'', (Winter 2004, Issue #116, Southern Poverty Law Center, retrieved April 8th, 2010</ref> The Order was also called the ''BrÃ¼der Schweigen'', or ''Silent Brotherhood''. ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == *[http://www.whty.org/ Glenn Millers Official Website], with much information on the White Patriot party.
